awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Design and Control of Networked Offshore Hydrokinetic Power-Plants with Energy Storage
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract:
Growing a vibrant clean energy industry will lead to major societal benefits by reducing pollution and creating a large number of jobs. In addition to well-established renewables like wind, solar and traditional hydropower, marine currents have the potential to diversify and significantly strengthen the global energy portfolio. This project will conduct basic research focused on extracting electrical power from marine currents using ocean current turbines. These turbines will operate near the sea surface in major offshore currents and will be interconnected in arrays. The project will address fundamental issues related to coordinated, safe, reliable, and robust operation of these turbines within the array for maximum energy production. Networked electrical interconnections between devices and energy storage will also be investigated, with a focus on efficiently feeding electrical power from an array of turbines to an onshore grid. A diverse population of Faculty and student researchers will contribute to this project, creating a heterogeneous network of scholars that will improve the infrastructure for research and education. Important findings from this project will be integrated with active education and outreach programs at Virginia Tech, the University of New Orleans, and Florida Atlantic University which regularly share research outcomes with the public through presentations, workshops, the web, conferences, and summer camp activities. Broader scientific and technological impacts are expected in the energy sector, ocean engineering and technology, marine vehicles and devices, as well as autonomy and control systems.

Ocean current turbines will be interconnected in arrays through a local feed-in which sends generated power to a grid. These devices will be affected by flow perturbations such as current shear, turbulence, marine waves, as well as the shear and turbulence generated by neighboring turbines. The overall project goal is to ensure autonomous, reliable and robust coordinated operation of these turbines for maximum energy production and proper power conditioning in the presence of realistic perturbations and sub-system failures. For this purpose fault tolerant flight control, supervisory switching control to manage sub-system failures, formation and network control for ocean current turbine farms with energy storage will be investigated. Novel control systems, which include active blade pitch angle control by leveraging helicopter flight control technology and modern multivariable constrained control techniques will be developed. Control algorithms will be created and evaluated using numerical representations of commercial devices to increase applicability and encourage transfer to the commercial sector. Power conditioning solutions that utilize energy storage will be developed and evaluated to collect power from multiple devices for transfer to shore and grid connection. The project will also investigate energy storage and regeneration through fuel cells or hydrogen internal combustion engines. Basic principles and experimental data series will be combined to create a comprehensive simulation for the entire storage system. The model will be able to provide steady-state performance data for system design and for operations scheduling and control. Modeling and numerical simulation advancements will enable development and testing of controllers on numerical representations with dynamics very similar to commercial marine turbines. These will provide solutions for testing and evaluating the developed controllers, as well as advancements to turbine performance prediction capabilities. Dynamometer and in-water testing data will help advance the developed technologies towards implementation. Methods and tools from diverse disciplines such as control systems theory and technology, hydrodynamics modeling, optimization, as well as numerical computation and analysis will be involved.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Several outcomes resulted from this collaboration between Virginia Tech (VT), the University of New Orleans (UNO), and Florida Atlantic University (FAU). This collaborative project advanced knowledge on marine energy harvesting using ocean current turbines (OCTs). FAU investigators lead advancements in the numerical simulation of OCT devices, as well as in the simulation of hydrodynamic interactions within an OCT array, OCT fault identification, and OCT Spatiotemporal Path Optimization. Numerical simulations were used to evaluate moored OCT performance for systems using both variable buoyancy and lifting surfaces for flight control. These simulations were used to evaluate flight controllers designed by VT and energy storage systems by UNO. More specifically, the following outcomes were achieved through the FAU led portions of this collaborative project:

1) Ocean Current Turbine Site Specific Flow Modeling: FAU led the development of algorithms for reducing the error in Acoustic Doppler Velocimeter (ADV) measurements, improving the quality of turbulence spectra created from open ocean measurements. Ocean current energy densities were quantified globally using drifter data, with a focus on areas targeted for ocean current energy production. This includes quantifying water depths in energy dense regions to assist with system design and optimization. Algorithms were developed for integrating ocean current data measured using Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs), including hurricane data, into developed numerical simulation platforms. This technique low-pass-filters ADCP data based on the instruments Doppler noise floor and then modifies the turbulent spectra utilizing the characteristics of the utilized low-pass-filter to create a smooth transition between these two data sources.   

2) Ocean Current Turbine Simulation: FAU led the development of numerical simulations for bottom mounted tidal turbines, buoyancy controlled OCTs, and lifting surface controlled OCTs. OCT simulations were developed for system designs created as part of this project which represent commercial-scale OCT systems moored to the sea floor within the Gulf Stream current. Numerical models of applicable sensors were integrated into these numerical simulations, providing realistic sensor feedback to control systems. To enable fault tolerant controller development likely sensor and mechanical failures were identified and integrated into the numerical simulations.

3) Ocean Current Turbine Performance Assessment: FAU led the assessment of a buoyancy-controlled OCT system for a wide range of faulty and non-faulty operating conditions. This included quantifying system performance using flow data collected during non-storm and hurricane conditions, as well as for a wide range of mechanical and sensor failures. A unique control co-design process was developed and used to optimize this OCT design for operations in the Gulf Stream current based on measured flow data.

4) Ocean Current Turbine Farm Modeling: FAU led the development of an ocean current turbine (OCT) farm model to predict hydrodynamic interaction between turbines operating in an array. This model was refined and validated using experimental data found in literature.

5) Ocean Current Turbine Fault Detection: FAU led the development of algorithms for identifying faults in OCTs using produced electrical power and create remaining useful life predictions. These algorithms will provide valuable feedback related to system health for planning/scheduling maintenance and for fault tolerant controllers.

6) Ocean Current Turbine Spatiotemporal Path Optimization: FAU led the development of spatiotemporal optimization routines for path planning to maximize the power produced by OCTs. These approaches utilize deep reinforcement learning and model predictive control algorithms and have been applied to both the buoyancy-controlled and lifting-surface-controlled OCT models. Paths generated by these algorithms provide achievable operating depth targets to OCTs for use by lower-level controllers that maximize produced electrical power. A resulting collaborative paper entitled “Integrated Path Planning and Tracking Control of Marine Current Turbine in Uncertain Ocean Environments” was selected as one of three finalists for the ASME Energy Systems Technical Committee (ESTC) Best Paper Award for ACC 2022.

7) Educational outreach and workforce development: A diverse group of students (11 undergraduates and 7 graduates) were part of the FAU team, many of whom participated in events where the project was discussed with a diverse audience. This includes the dissemination of findings through conference presentations, posters, and papers; as well as journal papers, MS thesis, and PhD dissertations.

In multiple presentations, this project sparked significant interest during discussions with undergraduate students. This resulted in 11 undergraduate researchers joining this project who were funded through Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) supplemental awards.

This project also served the education of 7 graduate students. Three Ph.D. students were partially funded through this project, and another collaborated with these students using a different funding source. Three of these students successfully defended their Dissertations and graduated with their PhDs, and the fourth is making good towards her PhD. Additionally, 2 MS students were partially funded through this project and a third collaborated on this project with funding through her employer. Two of these students have successfully defended their MS Theses, and the third is making good progress towards her MS degree.
